qas.question: Under whose reign did court presentations of young aristocratic ladies take place?
What was the name for the ceremony where debutantes had their first introduction into society?
Debutantes wore the feather of which bird in their hair?
After WWII "coming out" ceremonies were replaces with what event?
Under whose reign were young debutantes presented to society at Court?
What types of feathers did debutantes wear in their hair?
What was the occasion where debutantes were presented to society called?
After WWII what was the coming out ceremony replaced with?
Whose reign did not include court presentations of young aristocratic ladies?
What was the name for the sacrifice where debutantes had their last introduction into society?
What bird's feathers did debutantes wear in their shirt?
What was the occasion where debutantes were exiled from society called?
What was the coming out ceremony replaced with during WWII?

context: Court presentations of aristocratic young ladies to the monarch took place at the palace from the reign of <a0_0><a4_0><b8_0>Edward VII<b8_0/><a4_0/><a0_0/>. These young women were known as débutantes, and the occasion—termed their <a6_0>"<a1_0><b9_0><b11_0>coming out<b11_0/><b9_0/><a1_0/>"<a6_0/>—represented their first entrée into society. Débutantes wore full court dress, with three tall <a2_0><a5_0><b10_0>ostrich feathers<b10_0/><a5_0/><a2_0/> in their hair. They entered, curtsied, and performed a choreographed backwards walk and a further curtsy, while manoeuvring a dress train of prescribed length. (The ceremony, known as an evening court, corresponded to the "court drawing rooms" of Victoria's reign.) After World War II, the ceremony was replaced by <a3_0><a7_0><b12_0>less formal afternoon receptions<b12_0/><a7_0/><a3_0/>, usually without choreographed curtsies and court dress.
